description: “Thunderstruck” is based on a photo that I took in Styria on a hot Summer evening that finally cooled down after this thunderstorm. “Lightening in a Summer Sky” or “Styrian Thunder” would probably be better names, but I like AC/DC.

listing_name: Peace – Burial at Sea, after William Turner
description: Lukas Hauser's interpretation of Joseph Mallord William Turner' Peace - Burial at Sea.
This painting is based on a photograph that I took when I was on a surf holiday in Nicaragua.

listing_name: Skull of a Skeleton with Burning Cigarette, after van Gogh
description: My interpretation of Vincent Van Gogh's "Skull of a Skeleton with Burning Cigarette"
AKA Donald J. Trump. My interpretation of "Portrait of Henry VIII" by Hans Holbein the Younger. It's framed in a gold-stained wooden floater frame.

listing_name: Metamorphosis of Narcissus, after Salvador Dali
description: My interpretation of Metamorphosis of Narcissus by after Salvador Dali. Quite a bit darker... When you look from different angles, you can see the blues and other colours from the background shine through the top glaze.

listing_name: Exploding Sunflowers, after Vincent Van Gogh
description: While I was on the quest to discover my own artistic style, I was trying to paint like big masters, while adding a twist. This is one of my earlier paintings, where I was experimenting with thick impasto.

Have you ever felt like you are trapped in the gilded cage?
This was the title piece of Lukas’ debut exhibition.

listing_name: Only from inside, a hamster wheel looks like a career ladder
description: Only from inside, the hamster wheel looks like a career ladder.
This was my first ever self portrait, before I took any painting classes. My goal was to create a piece where I can capture my likeness.
Painted off a poorly lit photograph during a painting holiday with my dad and friends.
Inspired by Claude Monet's Water Lily Pond Paintings... with a twist.
I had the honour of painting Barrie last during Charlie Schaffer's painting class. He was such a great model and so much fun talking to. He had a very positive spirit and brightened up the class.

When I painted “Face Study III”, I was experimenting with bold brush strokes. This was one of the life studies that I created before painting the portrait of Barrie during Charlie Schaffer's portrait summer course at The Art Academy in 2018. That was a very intense, but also very insight...

I painted “Figure Study with Cushions” during my first painting course the Art Academy London. That was also my first time painting from life models. The course was taught by James Bland who isn’t only a great tutor who helped me massively to see colours and tones, but he’s also an amazing artist.
This was my first time painting off a live model. It comes in a white wooden floater frame.

listing_name: Paper Cups and our Throw-Away Society
